Executive Summary

Facility:  City of San Buenaventura Bailey Water Conditioning Facility



FACILITY DESCRIPTION:



The City of San Buenaventua (City) constructed the Bailey Water Conditioning Facility (Bailey WCF)  in the late 1970s to treat groundwater for iron and manganese.  The facility was expanded in 1998 to treat 11.5 million gallons per day of groundwater to help meet the City?s domestic water service demands.  A gaseous chlorine system is used at the Bailey WCF to oxidize the iron and manganese in the influent well water and to provide a chlorine residual for disinfection.  The facility is equipped with chlorine gas detectors and a chlorine gas scrubber system.



The facility normally operates without the presence of onsite personnel.  Operators and maintenance staff travel to the Bailey WCF from the City?s Operation Center at the Avenue Water Treatment Plant in Ventura.



CHEMICALS SUBJECT TO RISK MANAGEMENT PROGRAM (RMP) RULE



The Bailey WCF uses chlorine in quantities above the federal RMP and California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) thresholds.  One-ton cylinders of liquid chlorine are delivered to the WTP by truck.  Typically, the City stores a maximum of 9 one-ton chlorine cylinders onsite in a building equipped with gas detectors and an automatic emergency scrubber.



ACCIDENTAL RELESES DURING THE PAST 5 YEARS



The facility has not had any releases in the past 5 years that resulted in fatality, injury, offsite evacuation or property damage.



PROCES SAFETY MANAGEMENT ACCIDENT PREVENTION PROGRAM



The Bailey WCF is subject to state and federal Occupational Health and Safety Administration Process Safety Management (PSM) rule.  The City has implemented a stringent PSM safety program that includes the following elements:



* Review of the design of all equipment and controls for the chlorine system to ensure they are properly designed and installed.



* Updates of standard operating procedures to include specific information on s

afety.  All procedures are reviewed and certified annually.



* Initial safety training and refresher training every 3 years for all operators and maintenance staff.



* Procedures to ensure that all contractors working on the chlorine system receive the same training that the City provides to is own employees.



* Regular inspection of all equipment, monitoring systems and controls, with careful documentation of all inspections.



* Prompt corrective action for any non-conforming issues identified by the regular inspections.



* Rigorous safety reviews conducted prior to system startup, if any equipment or operations are modified.



* Rigorous investigation of any incidents that have the potential to have caused a chlorine release.



* Periodic evaluation of the safety records of all outside contractors that work on RMP or CalARP regulated processes.



* A site-specific Emergency Action Plan.



* Implementation of an employee participation program to ensure that all plant-wide staff are aware of the PSM program, and are actively consulted regarding safety issues.



* Independent audits of the entire PSM and RMP programs every three years.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROCEDURES



The City uses its Emergency Action Plan to provide step-by-step procedures for emergency response in the unlikely event of an accidental release.  The key elements of the Emergency Action Plan include:



* All plant staff members (including administrative and clerical staff) are trained in the specific elements of the program.



* The chlorine building is equipped with and electronic chlorine detector.  The chlorine detector has an audible alarm and alerts the City?s Central Operations control room in the event of a chlorine leak.



* In the event of a large release, Central Operations would immediately contact the City of San Buenaventura Fire Department.



* A team of City supervisors and operators are fully trained, certified, and equipped for hazardous materials (Hazmat) emerge

ncy operations to repair the source of an accidental release.  The Fire Department and the City Hazmat team would jointly participate in any such repair.



RECENT STEPS TO IMPROVE SAFETY



Based on the recent safety reviews that were conducted as part of the RMP update, no significant steps to improve operational safety were identified.  However, the City continues to improve and build upon its safety training programs.
